comments.text:
Sure, it's wrong for Wall Street to take bailout money from the government. 
It's wrong for anyone to take money from the govt, but our government 
subsidizes the poor way more than they do the rich. Hundreds of billions of 
dollars in foodstamps and unemployment benefits each year, not to mention 
the $1.08 Trillion our govt spends a year on tax credits, most of which go 
to the middle class and poor (Child tax credits, tuition tax credits, 
income tax credits, etc). Of course, you won't see TYT do a video on how 
much the poor get from the govt so long as they are pointing their fingers 
at the rich.﻿
comments.author: Maxwell Montgomery

comments.text: +Maxwell Montgomery Thread Troll

comments.text:

benefits, you don't see that as greed? Why don't you look up the word 
"greed" in the dictionary.
comments.author: Maxwell Montgomery

comments.text:
+kamarn1234 "Poor ppl dont do that shit."

comments.author: kamarn1234

comments.text:
"Federal tax breaks for corporations: The tax code gives corporations 
special tax breaks that have reduced what is supposed to be a 35-percent 
tax rate to an actual tax rate of 13 percent, saving these corporations an 
additional $200 billion annually,according to the U.S. Government 
Accountability Office.
Subsidies to the fast food industry: Research by the University of Illinois 
and UC Berkeley documents that taxpayers pay about $243 billion each year 
in indirect subsidies to the fast food industry because they pay wages so 
low that taxpayers must put up $243 billion to pay for public benefits for 
their workers."

Firstly, that $243 billion isn't a corporate subsidy seeing as it's going 
to the employees not the corporation itself. I think you know you're 
misrepresenting the information on that, though.
Secondly, although many corporations do in fact get tax provisions and 
credits from the $1.08 Trillion our government dishes out annually, it is 
the middle class and poor who receive most of our tax credits. Here is our 
effective tax rates by bracket:

Lowest quintile: -4.5%
Second quintile: -1.0%
Middle quintile: 3.7%
Fourth quintile: 6.2%
Top 1%: 24.6

(Congressional Budget Office)
As you can see, the poorest Americans actually get more back in tax credits 
than they paid into through their income. Do I smell wealth redistribution? 
(Note: this is the premise of my argument of which you have yet to address).

Secondly, you seem to have a naive understanding of corporate taxes. 
Although the average Effective Corporate Income Tax has dropped to roughly 
around 20%, corporations are still being bombarded with other taxes, 
property taxes, sales taxes, etc. The rate you need to look for is the 
Marginal Effective Tax Rate on corporate investment which includes sales, 
property, and income. This rate is currently averaged at 35.3%, the highest 
of any country in the OECD.

http://taxfoundation.org/article/us-corporate-effective-tax-rate-myth-and-fact 
OECD: 
http://www.oecd.org/about/membersandpartners/list-oecd-member-countries.htm

"2014 US MILITARY BUDGET $640 BILLION"

No problem with that. I support federal spending when it is going to create 
high-skill labor, especially when it is something that cannot (and SHOULD 
not) be provided privately. The hundreds of billions we spend on 
unemployment insurance and foodstamps, which eventually ends up at Walmart 
to create LOW-skill labor, is a different story. I'm curious, what is your 
stance on education? Do you believe an education is necessary to get a 
decent job that can support a family? Or do you believe a job that anyone 
can do should be able to support a family? Of course, I don't really expect 
a clear-cut answer of this question, but you're free to entertain me if you 
wish.

Keep in mind that I did not support the bank bailouts during the 2008 
crash. You call my facts 
"Lowinformation/Republican/Corporatist/Millionaire/Apologist bullshit" Well 
why don't you look at the 2008 bailout and check how many Democrats 
approved it and compare it to how many Republicans approved it.

I am a capitalist, not a corporatist. Like most Republicans.
comments.author: Maxwell Montgomery

comments.text:
+Maxwell Montgomery Bro, ur post is 100% Low 
information/Republican/Corporatist/Millionaire/Apologist bullshit. Take a 
look at some REAL numbers.
 2014 US MILITARY BUDGET $640 BILLION: 
http://pgpf.org/Chart-Archive/0053_defense-comparison. We spend more on 
defense than all developed countries combined.
Direct federal subsidies to corporations: The Cato Institute estimates that 
federal subsidies to corporations cost taxpayers almost $100 billion every 
year.
Federal tax breaks for corporations: The tax code gives corporations 
special tax breaks that have reduced what is supposed to be a 35-percent 
tax rate to an actual tax rate of 13 percent, saving these corporations an 
additional $200 billion annually,according to the U.S. Government 
Accountability Office.
Subsidies to the fast food industry: Research by the University of Illinois 
and UC Berkeley documents that taxpayers pay about $243 billion each year 
in indirect subsidies to the fast food industry because they pay wages so 
low that taxpayers must put up $243 billion to pay for public benefits for 
their workers.
Add it up, Corporate welfare costs us at least $543 billion every year. 
Many of these same multinational corporations getting corporate welfare 
also outsource good paying American jobs 2 China, Korea, India, etc. Poor 
bastards. 
Company ($-millions) 08-12 Profit 08-12 Tax 08-12 Rate
General Electric         27,518        –3,054      –11.1%
http://www.ctj.org/corporatetaxdodgers/sorrystateofcorptaxes.pdf
Then we have the corporate taxdodgers like GE earning massive $$$, paying 
no tax, + getting a fat fucking tax REFUND on top of it! BTW, in 2012, GE 
was only 1 of 43 mulitnational corporations that earned big $$$, paid NO 
tax, + got a huge refund.
The billions above do not even count the government bailout of Wall Street, 
while all parties have done their utmost to tell the public that they did 
not need it, that they paid it back, or that it was a great investment. The 
Atlantic Monthly estimates that $7.6 trillion was made available by the 
Federal Reserve to banks, financial firms and investors.
So, while ppl like u posted their Corporate/Millionaire apologist garbage 
all over the web, The Fed doled out $7.6 trillion to the poor banksters. 
FUN FACTS: The $7.6 trillion was used 2 give bonuses, salaries, etc, 2 the 
same crooks that caused the huge 2008 meltdown. Guess how many banksters 
were fined, fired, prosecuted, or jailed 4 causing the crash. ZERO!!! 
Why??? Because thanks to massive deregulation, every fucking thing the 
banksters did was perfectly legal!! Dude, it should b obscenely obvious why 
this shit happened + will continue 2 happen. Our Federal Government, 
Republicans + Democrats, have been purchased by the 'poor' multinational 
corporations, Koch brothers, etc.!!

*RECLAIM OUR DEMOCRACY! Get massive $$$$$ OUT of politics!!!! Support the 
Constitutional Amendment 2 overturn Citizens United!! Go 2:  *
*http://www.wolf-pac.com/** !!!!!*

comments.author: fattkattz55

comments.text:
I think there is an element of scape-goating going on with the bankers. 
Okay they asked for light-touch regulation, like all industries do. But it 
was up to our elected officials to just say 'no'. Blaming Wall Street 
bankers for being greedy is a little like chastising a prostitute for 
giving you herpes. ﻿
comments.author: trev moffatt

comments.text:
+pUnK eModUdE All the recessions since 1929 would have been catastrophic - 
if not for welfare, public housing, state subsidy of industry, mortgage 
relief etc, But instead of throwing subsidies at the unemployed and 
struggling industries - we're now throwing money at the banks.

However, one could argue the former was preferable on the grounds, it 
subsidized the poor not the rich, plus the national debt was better 
controlled.

On the other hand Monetarists argued that Keynesian intervention over the 
long term would bankrupt the country regardless, through hyper inflation 
and sluggish growth - what they use to call 'Stagflation'.

Ironically exactly where we are now.

Whatever, system you choose capital will eventually collapse. In the 20s it 
was selling on the margin, in the 70s it was the Oil Crisis, in the 80s it 
was computers, in 2000 it was Dot Com, in 2008 it was sub-prime mortgages, 
There's always a different reason - but the real reason is capitalism 
itself.
comments.author: trev moffatt

comments.text:
+trev moffatt U need 2 look at history, dude. FDR put commonsense 
regulations such as Glass/Stiegel on banks + Wall Street back in the 1930s. 
From FDR's administration until the massive 2007 crash there was NEVER a 
recession even close 2 being as horrific as 2007. Bill Clinton started 
things in motion by signing Securities Modernization Act (which repealed 
Glass/Stiegel among other necessary regulation). Bush 43 put banking 
deregulation on steroids and set the stage for the massive 2007 
crash/recession. SCOTUS gave us the Citizens United ruling in January 2010 
which opened the floodgates allowing special interests to b able 2 dump 
massive $$$ in2 elections, + Congressional/Presidential lobbying. Citizens 
United is what gave us the weak sauce Dodd/Frank attempt 2 reregulate 
banks/Wall Street. Citizens United is also largely responsible 4 Pres Obama 
putting banking/Wall Street friendly ppl in watchdog positions. Remember 
Tim Geithner(former Wall Streeter) as Treasury Sec???? We need 2 get 
massive corporate money OUT of politics!!!! Support the Constitutional 
Amendment 2 overturn Citizens United!! Go 2:  http://www.wolf-pac.com/ !!!!!
comments.author: pUnK eModUdE

comments.text:
+Alex Mondschein Bush was the main culprit - pushing his 'Ownership 
Society'. The property owning democracy reached critical mass 
spectacularly. The poor really shouldn't have been getting mortgages. The 
bail out was basically the social housing bill transferred onto private 
banks. Nice blue-sky thinking allowing the poor access to mortgages - 
however, what happens when there's a downturn in the economy, suddenly the 
poor can't meet their payments. I think they were even allowing people on 
welfare to get mortgages at one point, whilst at the same time they were 
cutting welfare, Basically the economics of ideologues rather than old 
fashioned government mandarins.
comments.author: trev moffatt

comments.text:
Nah you can't blame *that* recession on a cyclical dip. It was 
*historically* bad, the worst since the depression in fact. Somebody or 
*everybody* was at fault. I do agree with your original statement though. 
100%. Were (by in large most of) them reckless with subprime mortgages, 
fractional reserve banking,  high risk lending, and pushing 
adjustable-rates on people when they had to know what was about to happen? 
 *Yes* they did. However, your analogy with the hooker's good, but it's 
more like having an NFL game with no refs or a trial with judge. Of course 
there's going to be chaos. A lineman's job is to protect his QB, an 
attorney's job is to advocate for his client. If nobody's watching the 
lineman's gonna rip his man's facemask off and the lawyer's going to 
fabricate all kinds of evidence, badger/lead every witness and misinform 
the jury as to the requirements for a verdict.  An IB's job is to generate 
capital, which is fairly easy to do if *nobody's* watching. If we're gonna 
get into the finger pointing, there are 3 parties involved that all share 
*some* of the blame. The banks, the consumers (nobody wants to hear that 
but it's true. It wasn't a Madoff situation, where we just flat out got 
ripped off. We made bad investments, we were encouraged to do so, but 
still.... We didn't have to give them our money. This is why I believe Econ 
& finance should be a bigger part of the *mandatory* curriculum at the high 
school and college levels. We *make* kids read and analyze Hawthorne 
& Dostoyevsky (don't get me wrong, I'm a huge fan of russian lit, but for 
maybe 98% of those kids that means *nothing* to them. Just a mandatory 
English class... At the same time most majors at most schools don't even 
have 1 econ req. Or if they do it's macro 101, basic, and more theory 
than practice... Anyway). Anyway, point being a fully educated consumer 
paying attention to what was going on in 05-07, should've been able to read 
the tea leaves and get their affairs in order. But if I could only point 
one finger at one party, I'd choose the SEC, and I'd choose the middle 
finger. They were the allegorical "missing refs/judges". I mean  the FCIC 
report, in a nutshell, said "The SEC doesn't do a damn thing. Really ever. 
They're MIA and more than likely corrupt". Fuckin Eliott Spitzer, alone, 
did more to stop the bleeding than the entire SEC, and he was just a 
governor. Then *he* got caught with a hooker, and *he* was accused of 
corruption. It took them a decade to catch Madoff for ripping off tens of 
billions, but Spitzer's got a hooker, and that gets done in a week? No 
doubt in my mind that investigation was sponsored by Fannie Mae. The SEC is 
a joke. If anything they do more harm than good.
comments.author: Alex Mondschein

comments.text:
+Not Crazy Ultimately you give these people too much credit. They are 
idiots - their own grave-diggers. They genuinely believe freemarkets will 
bring greater wealth and prosperity to everybody who wants it. Its an 
ideological myopia that both politicians and bankers are still suffering 
from. Keynesians are also deluded to a lesser extent, thinking taxing the 
rich to help the poor was gonna fly over the long term.
comments.author: trev moffatt

comments.text:
+trev moffatt No, the bankers are not idiots. Everything they do is 
calculated.

The bankers cannot lose. They get paid regardless if they make money for 
others or not.
comments.author: Not Crazy

comments.text:
+Not Crazy I actually don't think the banks are really that culpable. Every 
recession there's always someone else to blame. The fact is capitalism will 
always bust every 30 years or so. Next time somebody else will carry the

comments.author: trev moffatt

comments.text:
Well, the bankers and the Bush admin knew exactly what they did. They carry 
100% of the blame and guilt.

The amount of money the banks can borrow was increased threefold to 30 
times the liquidity. (Try mortgage your home for "even" 10 times its 
value.) What happens when the stock market drops 5%, the bank's entire 
liquidity? 2008 happened.

Of course, they only lost "other people's money."

But there is an even more scandalous thing that followed 2008. Nothing.

More than 800 bank officials went to jail following the Savings and Loan 
crisis in the 1980s.

Following 2008 we have zero convictions, zero indictments, zero arrests of 
any of the elite, non-prime lenders.

It seems the USA no longer prosecute the rich and powerful. Why? Because 
they are in bed with politicians and the ones payed to keep an eye on the 
banks.

The FIAT currency system FORCED on the American people at gunpoint by

The people that run the Federal Reserve practice the Alchemy Of Rape.
Alchemy is the art of turning worthless material into something of value. 
The old dream of the alchemist was to make lead into gold. The new alchemy 
is the art of turning the paper of fiat currency into a device that steals 
human labor in perpetuity.
Fiat currency is the lubricant of the corporate state, used to rape the 
labor from generations of the world's population.
As long as fiat currency exists, there will be no law.
Fiat currency is warfare against the population by those who generate the 
currency.
Of course the petty gangsters of Wall Street will celebrate the bailout, 
mock the people that pay their way, and generally make asses of themselves.
Without the guns of government, the fiat currency system, and Wall Street 
fraudsters would wither away.
The real bad actor in this system is government. 
Until the private banking, fiat system is replaced, the people will 
continue to have their labor stolen by government.
Without a fiat monetary system, the War Machine would fall apart.
Crypto-currency has the potential to replace fiat currency.
To see Anna defend government is to see a young lady suffering from 
Stockholm Syndrome.﻿

comments.author: onaturalia

comments.text:
'"Recently, our nation's financial chieftains have been feeling a little 
unloved. Venture capitalists are comparing the persecution of the rich to 
the plight of Jews at Kristallnacht, Wall Street titans are saying that 
they're sick of being beaten up, and this week, a billionaire investor, 
Wilbur Ross, proclaimed that "the 1 percent is being picked on for 
political reasons."

Ross's statement seemed particularly odd, because two years ago, I met Ross 
at an event that might single-handedly explain why the rest of the country 
still hates financial tycoons -- the annual black-tie induction ceremony of 
a secret Wall Street fraternity called Kappa Beta Phi.

"Good evening, Exalted High Council, former Grand Swipes, Grand 
Swipes-in-waiting, fellow Wall Street Kappas, Kappas from the Spring Street 
and Montgomery Street chapters, and worthless neophytes!"

It was January 2012, and Ross, wearing a tuxedo and purple velvet moccasins 
embroidered with the fraternity's Greek letters, was standing at the dais 
of the St. Regis Hotel ballroom, welcoming a crowd of two hundred wealthy 
and famous Wall Street figures to the Kappa Beta Phi dinner."* The Young 
Turks hosts Cenk Uygur and Ana Kasparian break it down."﻿
